{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3342193,"name":"","username":"PunkMcFunk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/punkmcfunk/{size}/212702_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-25T00:54:55.632Z","cooked":"

This year while programing with CAN spark maxes it took a long time to get a robot so we were programing on a test board with just two spark maxes. An issue we kept having was that if our code initialized 6 sparks the driver station would error and disable the robot after enabling if we only had the 2 sparks on the can line. We had to comment out the others to test but kept having issues revolving around what got commented out and what didn’t.

Is there a way to have the driver station not disable the robot when it can’t find a CAN Spark Max?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2024-03-25T00:54:55.632Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":89,"readers_count":88,"score":57.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":459948,"topic_slug":"spark-max-can-shutdown","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63734,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/spark-max-can-shutdown/459948/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3342214,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-25T01:18:36.099Z","cooked":"

The driver station doesn’t know or care about what hardware your robot has on it. However, if your code throws errors/exceptions, it’s entirely possible for one to crash your code which will absolutely disable the robot (as it should).

That said, a CANSparkMax object referencing a CAN ID that isn’t found on the bus generally shouldn’t crash your code. I suspect your issue is something else and is just being masked by the large number of “device not found” messages in the logs

So if that is the case running code that checks the encoder, sets PID values, or sets motor speed to 0 could cause errors to shutdown the robot?

If that is the case would try functions be used to handle these errors while in the debug stage?

We use a boolean to indicate if a subsystem or component is available to instantiate or not. Then check EVERYWHERE for a null object that wasn’t instantiated before using it. Setting a simple boolean at the front of the code is about a million times easier and safer than commenting/uncommenting.
